38408816.review:
A good game to play if you wish to see the depths of Cawthon's imaginative genius, yet are too scared to open up Five Nights at Freddy's.

Trust me, this game is so much fun. It's one of the most difficult games I've ever played (I used a walkthrough pretty much the entire time), but it was worth getting to the end.

What makes it good:
*Characters that I could easily connect with and feel for
*The music is pleasant and easy to listen to
*The graphics are FANTASTIC (Cawthon might not be able to animate people very well, but his robots are amazing)
*Wonderful story with a touching message about...well, that's kind of a spoiler. Trust me, it's there.

I think the only major downside is just how miserably difficult this game is. This game features things such as:
*A time limit. If you don't complete the game in 15 in-game days, you're finished. That's it. You have to restart the game all over again (You might be able to load a save, but you'll probably still be replaying a huge chunk of the game). There are items you can obtain to lengthen the time limit, but these are somewhat rare. If this makes the game sound impossible, then don't worry: I completed the game without running out of time, and I'm not the greatest at games. Still, if it stresses you out too much while playing, then maybe you should forget about it.
*The boss battles. There is no explanation of what each move does or even how the battle works. Once you study a walthrough, it should make some sense. Even with an explanation, though, the battles are pretty tough. However, this brings me back to my previous point: if you fail, you get kicked out of the entire area, meaning you've just wasted half an in-game day. To increase your chances of a win, you have to wait until nightfall and collect some level-up items, meaning you've lost more time. Do not worry; those who are patient will figure it out.

You're probably scared to play this game now, but I think the journey to the end makes it worth it. It was a ton of fun for me, even with all the game's flaws, and that's why I recommend this game.

O grande problema desse jogo é que a princípio ele é bem confuso e difícil de entender assim de cara, fica muito mais fácil quando se lê o manual no jogo que tem nos arquivos do jogo (sério, é como se fosse um passo a passo o manual, não chega a estragar a graça mas explica 90% de tudo no jogo), eu só descobri que havia esse manual quando ja tinha zerado o jogo e depois de ler percebi que o jogo seria bem mais fácil se eu tivesse lido antes. Ele não te dá muitas pistas dos passos que tem que fazer e algumas coisas são na tentativa e erro, pode até tirar a vontade para algumas pessoas que não possuem saco ou que não gostam de coisas repetitivas, pois de repetitivo o jogo tem muita coisa, mas a cada vez que se avança na história mesmo muita coisa sendo repetitiva da uma vontade de continuar e ir até o final do jogo. 36091539.review:
Definitely a fun game...the second time you play it. And if you have the right monitor.

Pros?
-Detailed character designs
-Multiple gameplay styles
-Cheats ("It's not cheating if you pay good money for it")
-Unique ability sets for each character
-Bosses, revamped bosses, secret bosses, and a secret revamped bosses (jk on that last one)
-Fast-paced combat
-Day/Night cycles
-AMAZING COPYRIGHTED MUSIC!!!!

Cons?
-Character designs are a bit too...robotic (yes, I know it's a bad joke)
-Seriously, though. The characters aren't too memorable
-Little story
-Combat is VERY chaotic
-Cheats only get you so far (apparently, you didn't pay enough money for them)
-Transitions of gameplay can be offputting on a first playthrough
-Minigames act more as a burden (unless you know how to play ;)
-Second half of the game features the exact same boss. 4 TIMES!
-Secret boss has a single, very crushing flaw
-Time for cycles can be incosistant
-The music is copyrighted. Yes, I am certain Mr. Cawthon did buy rights for usage!
-No consequence for the "Bad Ending"
-No screen optimization. If you're computer's too small, you can't play.

All in all, the game is rather difficult to play (let alone win) on the first successful playthrough. After you learn how everything works, however, it becomes rather easy and quite fun. And, since it's free, why not check it out?
8.51/10.00

Now, if you'll excuse me, I need to petition for a TDH sequal.

35496614.review:
Pros:
- It's free
- Great atmosphere
- Amazing story
- Breautiful world and artwork
- The music (I just love the soundtrack)
- Boss Fights are awesome
- Exactly the right level of challenging
- Robots
- Space
- Robots in Space


Cons:
- you need to grind/farm a lot until you can beat the game. Since I suck at this I haven't beaten the game yet. 
- You have to figure out the controls all by yourself

Indiegames.com mentions in their review the "three distinct gameplay types." They are one of the things about The Desolate Hope that make the game so entertaining, even with the farming and grinding involved. But they also are the reason why some players are fed up with the controls. The game doesn't tell you which key does what, and you have to figure it out for every gameplay type and interface.

But since I'm a nice person I'm gonna explain the controls ;)

1) the normal mode, prior to entering a simulation: walk with arrow keys. Enter a simulation or pick up items by pressing down. If you want to drop an item, use your mouse to click on the [x] next to the item's icon. 

2) inside the simulation: walk by using the arrow keys, interact with merchants or virus by pressing down, purchase items from merchants by clicking on the item you want and jump/shoot by pressing x or y on your keyboard (x and z for QWERTZ-keyboards)

3) Boss battles: use your mouse to click on the attacks you want your robo-buddies to use. There is a combat-simulator for this right in the first room of the station.

4) Bonus: never ever hit ESC unless you really mean to end the game. 

Now go and give this game a shot. It's awesome, touching and fun to play :)

35300674.review:
[b][u]5 Things You Should Know about [i]The Desolate Hope[/i][/u][/b]
[b]What's Is It?[/b]
Action/platformer with a haunting tale of abandoned robots seeking purpose in a random universe. The story might very well be high quality, but I wasn't able to get very far because just figuring out [i]how to play[/i] was an intolerable farce of trial and error on the keyboard.  Games are supposed to be fun, and this one became a chore very quickly, unfortunately.

[b]What's The Best Part?[/b]
It's a game about a sentient (AI) coffee machine trying desperately to keep things running on an abandoned off-world space station that humanity seems to have forgotten about.  What's not to love about that set up?  Add in some genuinely beautiful graphics and price tag of zero... Seriously, why are we still talking about this?!

[b]What's The Worst Part?[/b]
The controls are highly non-intuitive, which wouldn't be so bad in itself if the game actually [i]explained what they were[/i].  It tells you the controls for the main platforming game play, so that's fine, but it doesn't give you any instruction about secondary interfaces, like merchant store menus or boss fights (which play entirely differently than the main platforming part.)  They're not at all obvious, either.  I seriously could not figure out how to buy stuff from a merchant.  There was no indicator of which item was selected.  Every key with a function that the game had told me about so far just exited the store panel without effect.  Up/down arrows?  Nope.  Left/right arrows?  Nope.  Shoot or jump keys?  Sucka!

I can handle a game that has non-intuitive controls, as long as the game [b][i]tells me what those controls are.[/i][/b]  Either in-game or in the main menu somewhere.  I can also handle a game that doesn't explain the controls, so long as those controls [b][i]are intuitive enough to figure them out myself.[/i][/b]  If I need to bust out Google just to learn what keys I need to press to buy a simple upgrade from a merchant, or to [i]do anything at all in boss fights,[/i] things have officially gone too far.  Games should be [i]accessible,[/i] even if they aren't [i]easy to beat.[/i]

[b]Will I Like It?[/b]
If you're okay with going to outside sources just to learn [i]how to play[/i], maybe you'll have a better experience than I did.  Personally, I was left feeling like the game was actively wasting my time by not telling me how to play it.

[b]Why Should I Buy It?[/b]
I mean, it's free, so go ahead and try it if you want to.

This has been a 5TYSK review. (#0013)

Here is an apple pie recipe. Enjoy! :)

INGREDIENTS
1/2 cup sugar
1/2 cup packed brown sugar
3 tablespoons all-purpose flour
1 teaspoon ground cinnamon
1/4 teaspoon ground ginger
1/4 teaspoon ground nutmeg
6 to 7 cups thinly sliced peeled tart apples
1 tablespoon lemon juice
Pastry for double-crust pie (9 inches)
1 tablespoon butter
1 large egg white
Additional sugar

DIRECTIONS
In a small bowl, combine the sugars, flour and spices; set aside. In a large bowl, toss apples with lemon juice. Add sugar mixture; toss to coat.

Line a 9-in. pie plate with bottom crust; trim pastry even with edge. Fill with apple mixture; dot with butter. Roll out remaining pastry to fit top of pie. Place over filling. Trim, seal and flute edges. Cut slits in pastry.

Beat egg white until foamy; brush over pastry. Sprinkle with sugar. Cover edges loosely with foil.

Bake at 375° for 25 minutes. Remove foil and bake 20-25 minutes longer or until crust is golden brown and filling is bubbly. Cool on a wire rack. Yield: 8 servings.

I love and hate this game. As an art piece, it's beautiful. I love the world and the animations which are incredibly detailed, and the story will keep you interested.

However, the gameplay is where it falls apart. The game has two main large problems: lack of tutorials and wasting time. The main focus, the bulk of the game, and indeed the best part of the game is boss battles. These are broken apart with platforming segments inbetween. You'd be best off spending a lot of time in the provided battle simulator, which is the closest thing to a tutorial mode for the boss battles, which could've used more explanation but is ultimately not as hard as it looks to grasp.

Everything in this game costs a tonne of points, which leads to it becoming a grindfest. One particular world you'll be visiting is underwater and is very slow to navigate. The game has a day/night cycle, though during the night you basically just play a minigame to level yourself up in boss battles, so it really just distracts and takes away from the main game which takes place during the day.

In summary, there is good here, but it's buried under layers and layers of inconvenience. For a free download, there's nothing to lose, so I'd still recommend playing it to see all the worlds and cool 3D models if nothing else.

Also, the music, though just royalty free stock music, is well chosen and a nice listen.

33805661.review:
Amazing little free game about saving an automated research outpost as a walking coffee machine. It's got a number of different mechanics, including a platformer inside of virtual environments, a very simple top down zelda-like shooter inside of virtual environments inside virtual environments, and a fast paced rpg combat system for fighting the virus that's assaulting the simulations.

The graphics are somewhat primitive 3d, but with a style that makes everything look surprisingly good. The environments can be a little confusing to navigate in some places but the initial exploration of the simulations is still fun. I'm in some of the later game virus fights and the game is definitely harder than I expected, but I'm not as good at micromanaging the RPG combat. The turns come really fast and on top of that there are minigames which your characters can launch which build up bonuses but have to be played while still controlling all of your actions.

All and all I'm really impressed with this game, it's got a lot of charm and I've paid money for games that were much worse. Definitely worth a try, especially if you like fast paced micromanagement. I don't think I've seen any other RPG combat systems like it.

32665334.review:
I bought this game a while back because the design looked interesting, though I didn't know what to expect, and sadly, it sat unplayed for quite some time because I didn't know anyhting about it.  By the time I got around to it, the game went free-to-play, and now you have no excuse not to play it.

The sci-fi premise here was a good one; without spoiling too much, a handful of AI's on a distant research station have a mission to run simulations to determine the habitability of a planet for human settlers.  Each AI has their own idea of how things will work best, and you get to experience each simulation through the course of the game.  A handful of intriguing twists are definitely what make this game worth the playthrough.

The visuals range from beautiful, to awesome, to ridiculous, to near-seizure-inducing.  The characters are interestingly designed and their simulations are fantastically imagined.  The research facility and simulations provide interesting contrast with the surrounding barren landscape under the quiet vacuum of a beautfiul starscape.  The battle sequences can be a bit much, at times producing effects fully intended to make them basically unplayable for a brief period.

Down to the gameplay, which was actually a lot of fun.  A pretty sizeable chunk of the game is presented in sidescrolling, platforming 2D.  You jump, shoot lazers, pick away at the story, and power up for your confrontations present in each simulation.  Those confrontations are frenetic turn-based RPG battles.  I must admit that even after completing the game, some mechanisms of those battles remain a mystery to me.  The battle display is a tad overwhelming, Information all over, attacks and effects constantly firing seemingly without reason, handful of minigames just doing their thing all at the same time.  There were a lot of neat design choices made here to make the battles seem very intense, while they really just boil down to most of the usual RPG elements served with great speeeed and clutter.

The soundtrack has some really cool jams.  While shuffling across the surface of the planet at night, I found myself just a little disappointed if I didn't allow the groovy bass parts to get heard before getting back into the station.  Each simulation has its own own sound that fits the AI's prodcued situation.

Above all the gameplay and art, If you can dig a good sci-fi, get this thing and enjoy yourself.

32437337.review:
The Desolate Hope is easily one of my all time favorite games ever it's fun to explore, find secrets and the RTS RPG battles are just so addicting and fun 

Pros
The art style I really like the way this game looks from the backgrounds to the individual character models everything looks great
The soundtrack is just incredible I love each and every track with the epic boss themes to all the mild exploration themes
The story is pretty good, intriguing and interesting to think about especially with some hidden easter eggs that help piece things together 
Each character is distinct and memorable in design, battle capabilities and personality my personal favorites would be Malenz, Alphus, Mirad, Bio-Beta and Coffee. Yes I'm aware that that's the extent of all the main characters but their all just really well done 
The gameplay it's pretty good and varied you have simple side scrolling platforming sections which are pretty good for the most part, overhead virtual dungeon crawler grinding hotspots which again are pretty fun especially if you can find all the secrets, walking while collecting stuff space invaders simulator is pretty relaxing and this part has a lovely background  and theme and finally the best part of the gameplay the RTS RPG battles! These battles are just super fun and feel really satisfying each of the 4 main robots ability's to succeed in battle depends on how well you manage all their ability's and believe me there are a ton of them to manage it may seem really complicated and hard to keep track of at first but after you get a good understanding of how each ability works everything just flows at an incredible smooth pace after that the end result will leave you feeling like an epic champion oh and as an added bonus you can shoot lazers and interact with NPCs in all these modes (the RTS RPGs don't have NPCs)
I really like the learning curve this game provides you can figure out how all the essential mechanics work on your own as long as you pay attention and well read the descriptions but even if you can't figure everything out and end up feeling confused the game comes with an instruction manual in the games properties that pretty much explains everything
The Writing was also pretty good and at times pretty funny to
The credits were pretty cool now that may seem like an oddly specific thing to praise but there's some cool stuff added into them like still images of all the bosses you defeated with awesome music and while on the subject of the end game I think it's worth mentioning that the ending was also pretty good
I like how after beating the game your still free to load back your save and explore for any secrets you may have missed or if your patient enough you can replay the game with all your upgrades intact
This game is free but if given the chance I would've gladly payed for it its just that good 

Cons
One of the platforming levels is an underwater level and like most games with a water level it kind of stinks
This game has a time limit through out the whole game granted it pauses for boss battles or the dungeon crawler bits and is kind of important to the story as well as how the game works and when your on your last stretch of days you can find items that extend how much time you have left and running out of time doesn't result in a game over but I'm still not a fan of time limits even if in this case you don't really have to worry about it it just adds some tension and makes the under water level super annoying
Malnez has a well designed level but it's annoying how you have to reach the very end of the level to talk to him when all the other levels have there respected characters close to the entrance
Bio-Beta's level can be a bit disorienting
A few names in the instruction manual don't match the in game names but you can still tell whos who and what not based off the descriptions
as you make progress in the game a static effect pops up in certain environments  combine this with how flashy the RTS RPG battles are and you have a game that could be considered epileptic so if you suffer from epilepsy you may want to avoid this game

so yeah I really enjoyed this one and considering that it's free the only reason I wouldn't recommend it is if your epileptic but other than that I'd totally recommend this one as one of my favorites

Beautiful, surreal, engaging. The Desolate Hope is many things, including overlooked. This game is a fasinating blend of side-scrolling action, top-down shooting, and active-time RPG. The graphics is beautifully detailed and surreal pre-rendered 3D that puts FNAF to shame, the plot is very interesting so far, and the gameplay varies so often that it's hard to get bored. 

It DOES have an issue with not explaining gameplay mechanics, but you learn things pretty quickly, and a big issue with constantly having to change hand positions between the mouse and keyboard - something easily fixed with alternate/unified keybindings between modes (having to select options with the mouse while moving with the arrows is a pain, when the side-scrolling sections have you using Z and X, which could easily be mapped to Yes and No).

The short answer is: this isn't like anything you've played before, and greatly deserves a look.

31424572.review:
I highly recommend this game for many reasons. This game not only has an enticing story that involves really awesome futuristic character designs, and a really cool setting, but the gameplay is very interesting because it changes the gameplay style in multiple ways. If you enjoy side scrollers, this game has side scrollers. If you enjoy RPG style boss fights, this game has RPG style boss fights. I honestly feel that this is one of the most underrated games that the online world has to offer. Now of course, the game does have some flaws to it that I'll mention just so I don't look like some blind follower of the game.

One flaw that the game has that I'll point out is that the game, while looking amazing at times, can have the occasional moment where something just looks really out of place, and it can take away from the experience if you are very picky about graphics, and art style.

Another flaw would be that sometimes the characters just keep talking for a very long time, and it can drive someone to just start skipping through a lotof dialouge that's very important if you care a lot for the story of the game like I do.

One final flaw I'd like to point out that can also be considered pro, it that a lot of the time, you're forced to start grinding the game's currency, and trying to find the merchants because at some points, the bosses become so difficult, the level of your characters don't matter, and what really matters is buying as much stuff that benefits you as possible. Now, you can either take that as a pro, or a con, I can see both sides.

So, that's my review on Desolate Hope, definetely in my top 5 for favourite games, and something I highly recommend!

31352380.review:
I was eying this before it became free, some time around when it was first released. It seemed different.
After getting this when it was made free to play, I suggest anyone curious to give it a shot. By no means is this quirky little game a masterpiece, but it is interesting and different, by its own right. And it is undeniably different than Scott's claim to fame in FNAF - in a great way.

The controls are a little stiff, and could be better. And having no options to pause the game, nor settings available that I can see is a little odd. It just wants you to hop in and play. 

The graphics are really nicely done, and have an older feel to them. 
The gameplay is a mix of resource management and metroidvania exploration. 
The boss fights seem bizarre old school JRPG style with a lot of colors, flashing lights, and strange techniques. 
The story and setting are the biggest draw, a cyberpunk style throughout it all, with an aloof humor in the machines and their visions of a perfect human habitat, in a forgetten corner of space.

I could probably play through the whole thing in one sitting, and this is based off my initial impressions. I forgot what the price was originally, but I would have regretted paying more than 2 bucks max for this. But for free, it's worth a shot.

30783797.review:
The game is heavily narrative driven, and a is an interesting character exploration of how different "people" deal with terrible situations, mania, and the inevitably of death. You do this while piloting a sarcastic coffee pot. It is that sort of game.

This is...a dramatically odd bird. Mainly, it's a side-scrolling platformer/shoot'm-up. Mainly. But the boss fights are done as a realtime rpg format (And are insane - both fun wise and concentration wise), and the level of your fighters for it are based around a very linear scavenger hunt that dips into space invaders on occassion. And then there are small top down sections. just because XD

In a lot of ways, this game feels vaguely like Master Blaster, on the old NES, if smaller and with the added rpg elements. The game runs a couple hours, and has limited replayablity - I'm only really interested in seeing the ending again. But it's free, so...still totally worth it.

The music is nice, if potentially repetitive, and the graphics are good, in a gritty way that re-enforces the themes. The controls are pretty solid, and the characters are interesting and weirdly believable. The difficulty is generally pretty good, though it spikes hard in the last few boss fights. under normal situations, these last fights are hair tearingly difficult - but certain secrets can make it a cake walk, if you are willing to grind money to a painful degree. Which is...kind of the worst of both worlds? 

The one other big downside is that the game has a twist...but it isn't hard to guess - the main thing keeping the twist hidden is that there are 4 or 5 other possible twists obscuring it. 

However, the game ends with a very good finale - including a monologue so good, that I cried trying to tell someone about it afterwards. It's really quite good.  I won't spoil it here XD

And it's free now, so, why not?!

30382914.review:
This is a wonderful little game (clocking just over 8 hours) with a mixture of different gaming elements to please folks. We've got platforming, high-animation turn-based combat, fetch quests, and a nod to an old school classic alien shooter. The control scheme for most of the game is ridiculously simple, so it's very approachable, but it maintains its challenge in different ways. Some of the game play around the platforming and questing can feel repetitive, but it's never a waste of time, since you're on the clock. Boss battles are a spectacle, and though I wasn't exactly sure what each of my attacks might have been doing, that didn't diminish my pleasure at each victory. All these are held together by a compelling story and two unlikely characters who keep you motivated to see the ending. 

The graphics were rich and imaginative, and they serve to reinforce the theme of the game's title. The soundtrack is also well-tuned to each stage of the game. 

I was thoroughly pleased and impressed.

29306211.review:
The Desolate Hope baseia-se numa original narrativa de ficção científica onde os humanos procuram novos planetas para habitar. Para isso usavam robôs, estes eram enviados para o espaço e colonizavam o planeta, preparando-o para quando os humanos chegassem. Este projecto era repetido em massa e como tal, alguns dos planetas eram postos de parte ou esquecidos. No caso do jogador, ele é uma máquina de café cujo programa quer ajudar a eliminar os vírus que atacam os diferentes robôs da sua estação, num planeta desconhecido. 
    Os elementos visuais deste jogo são um dos seus pontos fortes, um grafismo que me faz lembrar principalmente H. R. Giger misturado com tantas outras obras de sci-fi dos anos 80. O gameplay mistura vários estilos como RPG, plataforma e aventura e batalha por turnos, tornando este uma das melhores experiências e maiores revelações para mim uma vez que não esperava muito de um jogo gratuito. Sim, gratuito!
    A narrativa excelente lança uma crise existencial, questionando se valeu ou não salvar as criações e simulações das máquinas em função da sobrevivência e evolução do ser humano, não sabendo se esta se concretizou de facto. Desperta sentimentos no jogador que nos obrigam a desejar uma sequela, ardentemente.
    Tanto da parte da jogabilidade como da parte da narrativa este jogo é uma surpresa, um "abre olhos", lembrando a comunidade Gamer de que jogos Indie e jogos gratuitos podem ser autênticas obras primas, mesmo que esteja-mos habituados a encarar esta classe de jogos como inferiores e rudimentares. Scott Cawthon dá também uma lição à comunidade de Game Developers, dá um grande exemplo de modéstia tornando esta sua criação tão acessível, enquanto outros, com obras piores ou iguais as lançam a preços exorbitantes. Esta modéstia foi com certeza um ponto adjuvante na sua fama e sucesso com obras posteriores como a saga Five Nights at Freddy's.
    Uma obra superior em todos os parâmetros na minha opinião, recomendo a 100% e a todos os géneros de público.

26024907.review:
J’étais sur le chemin du retour. Les nuages tiraient à vue. La pluie battante me percutait la tête et l’épaule, frappait les corps, frappait le sol dans un concert de percussions désorganisé où une centaine de batteurs fous se défoulent sur leurs caisses claires la langue pendue, secouant le gras de leurs crinières comme autant de bouteilles de soda prêtes à exploser. Jamais ou presque je n’avais vu telle averse. Le déluge. Alors que Dieu avait oublié de fermer le robinet du ciel, les pavés du trottoir se noyaient sous une couche d’eau de moins en moins fine. Les têtes des parents s’abritaient sous les enfants qu’ils calaient sur leurs épaules et les chihuahuas en panique grimpaient sur des emballages MacDonald en espérant y trouver leur arche de Noé.  Emmitouflé dans une grosse doudoune aussi chaude et sûre que le ventre d’une mère, je fus stoppé par le couinement d’un vieillard affalé en désordre contre un mur et entre deux poubelles. Je m’arrêtai et fixai sa silhouette désagréable. Il allait ouvrir la bouche pour que je puisse y compter les trous. Son haleine n’avait que le mérite de masquer son odeur de chien mouillé. «Vous n’avez pas une petite pièce ? Je n’ai pas de maison et je n’ai pas mangé depuis dix jours.» A ces mots, j’attrapai devant lui mon porte-feuille pour en sortir ma carte de métro, lui tournai le dos puis m’engouffrai vite dans le ventre de la ville sans un regard pour mon interlocuteur. Mon argent irait plutôt enlargir la panse de Gabe Newell où il serait plus heureux.

Enfin arrivé devant mon écran d’ordinateur, je me posai dans le moelleux de mon fauteuil à roulettes hors de prix. La scoliose qui ronronnait de plaisir, j’allumai mon unité centrale, prêt à dépenser mes euros jalousement gardés pour ce jeu aux superbes artworks qui m’avait fait de l’oeil ce matin. Et là, la surprise. L’ébêtement. Merde alors, The Desolate Hope est gratuit. Mais genre vraiment gratuit. Pas la moindre petite trace de micro-transaction. Je baissai les yeux et regardai mon porte-monnaie rembourré de pièces et de billets. [i]Mais qu’est-ce que j’vais faire de tout cet oseille ?[/i]

Qu’est-ce que The Desolate Hope ? Un Metroidvania ? Un vieux Zelda-like ? Un jeu de rôle ? Un jeu d’aventure, peut-être ? Aucun des quatre. Mais un peu des quatre quand même. The Desolate Hope explore plusieurs pistes de game design mais n’en pousse aucune assez loin pour en mériter l’appartenance au genre. The Desolate Hope est surtout un jeu qui ne nous abreuve pas de dicactitiels et nous donne l’impression de vite nous abandonner dans son monde comme un sale gosse jeté de la voiture sur le bord de l’autoroute. [i]Maintenant démerde-toi.[/i]

La première heure de jeu est assez confuse. [i]Hein ? Je dois faire quoi ?[/i] Beaucoup de non-dits ne demandent qu’à être entendus à l’expérience, on retrouve ce goût de la débrouillardise qui a fait les grandes sensations des meilleurs jeux des deux décennies passées. On pense alors être face à un game design à assimiler tout seul, comme un grand. Trop content d’être enfin en face d’un défi intellectuel, la curiosité piquée par une direction artistique sublime qui nous servira de carotte, on décide d’explorer ce monde étrange et mélancolique qu’on ne comprend pas très bien. On chute un peu. On se cogne aux murs. Ce n’est qu’au coût de quelques écorchures et d’un grand courage qu’on commence à se dresser sur les deux pattes arrières. Au milieu de l’effort, quand la douleur du muscle nous hurle d’arrêter, on ne cède pas mais continue de pousser fort, alors on exulte, fiers d’être persuadés d’avoir appris à marcher tout seul, debout comme un grand singe. L’excitation retombée, on commence à sentir la pression sous nos aisselles. On se retourne et découvre alors qu’on était simplement tirés par les bretelles.

Parce que quoi qu’en dise la première impression qu’il laisse, The Desolate Hope n’est pas du tout un jeu qui nous abandonne à notre sort ; oui son univers nous déstabilise, oui il y a beaucoup de choses à comprendre par soi-même, oui certains aspects vitaux du game design ne nous seront jamais expliqués mais non, nous ne sommes jamais seuls. Le jeu regorge d’indications, nous tient par la main du début à la fin et les niveaux sont assez étroits et peu nombreux pour être très, très vite assimilés. The Desolate Hope est un jeu qui pourra vous faire peur mais n’est finalement pas plus dangereux qu’un pistolet qui crache un drapeau [i]BANG![/i]. Les pics de difficulté qu’on rencontrera (essentiellement les combats contre les boss) ne viennent jamais du fait qu’on ne sache pas quoi faire ni où aller : ce sont des obstacles posés sur notre route pour nous inviter à chercher ailleurs dans le jeu des combines pour les surmonter. Un chouilla de débrouillardise suffira à vaincre les plus grandes difficultés, à l’exception peut-être du dernier ennemi, assez redoutable pour nous demander un peu plus d’efforts.

Comme Dead Rising, Pikmin, Majora’s Mask et les autres meilleurs jeux du monde, TDH est un jeu « sablier », c’est à dire un jeu que l’on est chronométré pour finir. Mais là encore, la menace n’est qu’illusoire. Pour diverses raisons que la balise [spoiler]spoilers[/spoiler] me fera taire, il sera plus difficile d’échouer par manque de temps que d’arriver au générique de fin.

The Desolate Hope n’est donc pas un défi facile mais certainement pas un insurmontable. Vous aurez peur au début, serez rassurés par la suite, vous aurez un pic de trouille un peu plus loin et serez soulagés sur la fin. Depuis un HUB régi par le cycle jour-nuit (certaines actions ne sont disponibles que de jour et d’autres ne le sont que de nuit), on se promène dans un monde d’apocalypse douce, entre les vestiges d’une planète qui n’a jamais connu la vie et des simulations informatiques qui n’auront bientôt plus d’énergie. Le gros du jeu se joue comme un Metroidvania à deux touches où le besoin d’un objet ou d’une compétence nous force à faire des allers et des retours entre ses quatre niveaux. A l’intérieur de ces niveaux, on tombera sur des combats de RPG à la japonaise en ATB (active time battle façon Final Fantasy) et des séquences vaguement inspirées d’un Zelda en vue de dessus. Mélange habile des genres qui n’excelle dans aucun de ses différents gameplays, TDH est surtout une aventure visuelle, magnifique de tristesse, qui nous enlace dans son ambiance si particulière.

Cinq robots ont continué d’exister sur une station coloniale abandonnée par l’espèce humaine. Dans seize jours il n’y aura plus d’électricité. Comme les milliards d’humains et d’animaux qui s’agrippent à la surface d’une planète trop occupée à tournoyer au milieu du rien pour les entendre, The Desolate Hope ne nous fait lever les yeux vers un ciel vide que pour nous faire comprendre qu’il n’y a que le sol. Et ainsi mettre un nom sur ce poids qui nous pèse : l’expérience de la solitude à plusieurs.

25358241.review:
It feels definitively amateurish in terms of gameplay

*The platforming segments have nice backgrounds and soundtrack, but they are dull (little more to do than spamming your shooting and collecting chips that are just laying there), the enemies have cool designs but all of them just have one form of attack which is shooting pathetic energy balls at you, and since the simulations are actually pretty small it gets really repetitive in the late game

*The wireframe top-down segments are even more bare, its just looking for hidden corridors while shooting down mostly static enemies, it is somewhat more challenging than the platforming tho since bullets are harder to dodge and healing is not as easy, but overall they feel more like a tacked-on feature that was added onto the game to make it a little more varied rather than an actual part of it

*The boss battles are definitively the best part of the game, they are fun, challenging, and confusing in a good way that makes you interested in learning better how they work, but I think they are unbalanced, enemy moves are disproportionately stronger than yours even taking in account it's 4 vs 1, sometimes the bosses destroy you if you even drop your guard one second, sometimes you destroy them 10 seconds into the battle if you get a little too strong for them and late in the game hacking chips practically become mandatory in order to beat them

*There is little to do on the base other than go look for stuff on the outside and bringing it back to the Derelicts, it would have been nice if this part of the game was handled in a more interactive way

It might just be suited for people looking for something unusual and up to tolerate the clunky gameplay for it, but despite all it's shortcomings I think it was pretty good and ambitious for a free game made by one person, it makes me wish Scott did more than endlessly milk FNAF because this shows a lot of promise

The Desolate Hope es un juego de Scott Cawthon, creador de la famosa saga de terror, Five Nights at Freddy's; aqui controlamos a unos robots en un plataformero y RPG tactico y sobretodo, MUY DIFICL.

HISTORIA:
Lun Infinidus es una base donde hay unos robots que en sus dias eran protectores de sus planetas y se les consideraban dioses, al extingirse la raza humana, estos robots ya no funcionan muy bien y no pueden hacer nada más que quedarse sentados, reproducir repetitivas simulacines y ver como el suministro de energia de Lun Infinidus se termina, para que se apagen para siempre.

Controlamos una cafetera que debe entrar en las simulaciones de dichos robots para eliminar el virus y asi que vuelvan a funcionar; el juego tiene muchos eastereggs y referencias a personajes que luego saldrán a FNaF (como Bonnie, o Betagrid 0.9 que se parece muchisimo a un nuebo personaje de FNaF: SL.

- gran BSO

CONTRAS:
- Algo dificl de netender, al principio.
- Dificuldad muy elevada.

NOTA FINAL: 94/100 (Muy recomendable)

24164051.review: The Desolate Hope at first glance will seem like a very strange game, but after playing through it for a bit the game really shows how much of a gem it really is. You play as a coffee pot tasked with removing a virus from 4 robot's internal systems in order to keep the station running. While inside the robot's programming/system the gameplay functions as a platformer while you look for the virus to fight. The platforming is pretty fun giving you plenty of mobility allowing you to explore the numerous environments. When you encounter the virus the game changes to a rpg style real time turn based fighting system. The boss fights are super fun and very fast paced which can be great and enjoyable, or very deadly if you are not paying attention. There is a time limit represented by a day/night cycle which does add some tension, but more time can be added on during the night cycle if you find battery packs. The night cylce is when you can leave the hub world and search for items to level up the robots which are the memebers of your party during boss fights. One of my favorite aspects of this game are the graphics, the robots look great and really look intimidating while also looking somewhat cartooney. The Desolate hope is a great game that you can enjoy even if you dont like the five nights at freddys games, and the best part? Its FREE.

23833298.review:
NOTE: In the event that you suffer from Epilepsy or are otherwise sensitive to flashing lights, I do not recommend this game for your own safety.

Yes, my playtime is low, but I've played this before I found out there was a Steam version.

What is The Desolate Hope?

It was one of Scott Cawthon's earlier projects before he struck it big with FNAF, and is a spiritual sequel to an even earlier game of his. It's genre is hard to describe, but if you're asking me it is a an RPG with some Metroidvania and Time Management elements, but the real meat comes from its turn-based boss battles (even Cawthon admits to this).

You play Coffee, a sentient percolator on board the Lun Infinus space station. The space station is home to four (technically five, though one has since broken down) robots called Derelicts, who were tasked to create the ideal colony for humans by running simulations. Unfortunately, the Derelicts have been running far longer than expected, and a virus has started to worm its way into the simulations and wreak havoc. As Coffee, your job is to go to the simulations and locate the viruses, and the Derelicts will fight the virus off (the aforemented boss battles).

Gameplay is split into 3 parts;

[olist]
    [*]The first part is the Time Management aspect. The Lun Infinus has only 15 days worth of power left so you have to decide what to do. The day segments are when you go to the simulations and try to locate the virus, while the night segments have you scavenge for various trinkets that increase the stats of the Derelicts during the boss battles.
    [*]The second part is the Metroidvania aspect. While inside the simulation, Coffee jumps from platform to platform, shooting hostile programs that inhabit the simulations. Aside from zeroing in on the virus (which you'll have to do 3 times per simulation), you can purchase upgrades for yourself or the Derelicts -some of which are necessary to progress-, making it easier as to go through the game.
    [*]The Boss Battle aspect, and the real show stopper. This is where the Derelicts fight the virus (which thankfully does not consume time). It's semi-turn-based, in that the Derelicts and the Virus have a bar that fills up during the fight, and when it fills up, the Derelict/Virus can do an action. There's a lot of things that can happpen during the fight (especially with upgrades), though there's several ways to automate certain actions to take some load off.
[/olist]

Pros:
[list]
    [*]Catchy Music. Unfortunately, Scott cannot provide us with a soundtrack, not that this stopped players from finding the songs he used.
    [*]Incredible graphic style and character design. Seriously he really should focus on this more than FNAF.
[/list]

Cons:
[list]
    [*]Metroidvania aspect can get a bit tedious, especially if you're farming cash for upgrades. And this is coming from a seasoned Warframe grinder.
    [*]There is no Pause Button. Jokes aside, there's no way to pause gameplay (outside of a certain area that can be accessed in the simulations) so you better have some water nearby.
[/list]

Do I recommend this game?
Yes, if you can allot some time to it and if you're willing to withstand the Metroidvania bit. The boss battles are well worth it.

23357568.review:
Let's face it, this game has some flaws, balancing issues being the most prominent. Seriously, I was able to just mow over every boss in the game by simply unlocking all the conditionals and setting them all to stun the boss for one second. Except for one conditional, which I set to "Charge Tweak" the boss every ten seconds. However, when trying to play the game with a diverse set of conditionals, I found myself being constantly mowed over. So yeah, there are flaws.

I will admit that there is a lot of room for forgiveness here because the game is completely free to play, no signup or anything. You simply download the game and play. I feel like I would probably still recommend this game to people if it cost money, but only if it didn't cost more than $5.

So what exactly is "The Desolate Hope"? It is a game made by Scott Cawthon, who is best known as the mastermind behind the "Five Nights at Freddy's" franchise. He made this game two years before the first FNaF was released, but it apparently didn't get onto Steam until 2014.

This game is a blend of three different game genres: 2D platformer, top-down dungeon-crawler, and JRPG (kinda). You start in the "real world", then gain access to four different digital worlds to explore. The "real world" and the four digital worlds are the "2D platformer" part of the formula. While you are within these digital worlds, there are terminals scattered about that you can access. When you access them, you are dropped into a digital world within the digital world where you can farm for money and unlock conditionals for boss battles. This is the "top-down dungeon-crawler" part of the formula. After speaking to a respective digital world's Derelict, you can find and confront the boss in what is basically a JRPG-style battle, but without the turn-based element. This is the "JRPG (kinda)" part of the formula.

Since I've only played through it once, I'm a bit unsure what I would have to say about the game in terms of replay value. While I'm not eager to jump right back in and play through it again, there isn't anything preventing me from playing it again.

Also, let me just say that the demonstrational videos on the store page don't do the game's aesthetic justice. Seriously, this is actually a very pretty game. And that soundtrack! Tasty!

The story is suprisingly engaging, regardless of the fact that you are kept in the dark about what is actually happening for pretty much the entire game, right up to the final boss. The ending is definitely interesting to say the least.

So would I recommend it? Yes. I would definitely say this is something you should at least try. No money changing hands, no signup, nothing to make you regret downloading the game if you don't end up liking it.

This was one hell of a motherfking grind. I've clocked in around 17 hours, and saw some people finish it in half the time, not exactly sure how. But yeah, [i]the grinding. [b]My god.[/b][/i] Full immersion into a miserable long-forsaken space station right there.

The main problem here is that boss battles don't properly scale with the gameplay; so it starts out innocently enough, yet becomes more atrocious with every new one. So why do I recommend this game?

Well, I don't always care about gameplay first and foremost. While it's true I will be highly attracted to original games (and this one is all over the place), I'll play anything that has a great story. You can find a shtload of mysteries to progressively dig through, along with a cast of characters with different philosophical perspectives. I couldn't ask for more. (Actually, I wished for more dialogue. There was definitely untapped potential there.)

21976836.review:
Astonishing. A work of art, both visually and story-wise. This game features some of the best visual work I've ever seen, with a real '90s hyperfuture feel. Gorgeous. Story is subtle and effective, a tale of isolation, helplessness, and the terror of uncertainty. Characters are philosophical and devastatingly tragic, doing a good job of exploring the big question: Why do we even?

I know why I even. To jack up spooky cybertards with the help of my robot pals. In the not-too-distant future.
Great fun game, ten out of ten, here's my firstborn.

I was thrown at first by the simplistic gameplay. You derp around on rails to access the main platformer levels and eventually do some goofy top-down goofing. I eventually figured out the roles of these parts of the game: Basically you need to earn FAT STACK$ and buy hella upgrades to have any chance of winning the game, and you gotta do it fast-like before the landlord flips the breaker and things go dead. Yeah.
But you're here to fight a virus, and that's the main draw of the game. The battles are intense, complicated, and unforgiving; they're the only serious or difficult parts of the gameplay. You need to derp around the research station to access all the simulated worlds and to level your characters for battle. You need to explore each simulation carefully to find upgrades for your fine robo-dudesmen to use in battle, and to actually locate and challenge the manifestations of the Virus to initiate battle. You gotta enter the source-code world to get sweet conditional buffs for your battles. You gotta GIT GUD to beat the living hell out of robotic cyber-nightmares. IN BATTLES.

Found a little glowing fireball? Activate it. Pull up your big boy pants.
...
And yes, you have to fight THAT. No, don't slam the escape key. Not that you can beat it first time. Haha, no. 
You gotta GIT GUD.

It's time to micromanage four different characters with different move sets JRPG style, but *in real time*, trying to out-murder a terrifying robo-devil of some description while he is continuously jacking up yo boys with MIND LIGHTNING. Like a good frantic multitask in the morning? The final moves of each of your characters start little minigames *to be played at the same time* on top of the main battle in order to get some powerups. All this, and the virus is no sissy either. The difficulty ramps steeply, and the game is unforgiving if you are too slow or waste a move.

Fortunately, you get a practice arena in which to learn the ropes and PLENTY of fights in which to hone your skills. And failing a fight only sets you back in time- no resources are permanently used up, and you can try again. It's a good implimentation of super-crazy death challenges.

It's astoundingly addictive. Loads of fun.

P.S. I note how most other reviews have either fewer than 3 or more than 10 hours of play. I reckon a first-time playthrough would take ~9 hours, so there's how you tell if somebody actually finished the thing. I definitely took a full hour to get familiar with the game, but then I was hooked good and firmly. 
The ending is delightfully bittersweet. I hope you enjoy the heartfeels.

P.P.S. Malentz is my favorite character. His outlook on life is eerily similar to my approach to College. I like how he's the biggest, spikiest, spidery-est robot, but collects toys and spends his time tinkering in his Farmville-style hermitage. He's also got the best moves, though there's competition from that big loveable teddy bear Alphon.

21096155.review:
It's obvious that everyone's first thoughts about this game generally compare it to FNaF, and that's understandable. As a big FNaF fan (now Scott Cawthon fan) I did the same thing, and I still do occassionally as I'm going through. However, I think it's important to note that this is not FNaF and FNaF has nothing to do with it. 
The Desolate Hope is an amazing game, and even though it probably will never be as popular as FNaF, I hope that someday Scott can turn out another game similar to this one (assuming that developing games is something he wants to do for a long time). The visuals are amazing, I've actually just set one of the scenes from the game as my wallpaper. The characters are loveable as hell, each having unique and interesting traits. Gameplay is, foor the most part, very fun. Music is well done, fitting to the atmosphere and easily getting into my head for hours (in a good way!). I'm a sucker for this old but beautiful graphic style, and sci-fi settings, so this game is like a little slice of gaming heaven for me. (Also I would die to have a game visually and atmospherically similar to this one, but have it be a hidden object/puzzle game rather than an RPG~)
My only complaints with this would have to be some aspects of gameplay. The nights drag on, and are pretty much just a lot of holding down the left arrow key, especially after you've gotten the wrench and have no incentive to care about how efficient you are in your nightly collecting. Another thing I took issue with was the real-time combat with viruses. I often find myself flustered and frustrated, which makes strategizing difficult. Lastly, if you want more upgrades, there's a good chance you'll be grinding in those little terminal worlds for money for quite a while, which I find really annoying. 

tl;dr : this game is freaking awesome and beautiful, but the gameplay can be frustrating.

19450616.review:
Coffee saves the day in this bizarre RPG-sidescroller hybrid, The Desolate Hope. In it, you play a small video game program tasked with exploring several unique worlds and battling viruses within as per the orders of a coffee machine tasked with maintaining the extra-planetary colony of Lum Infinis. To aid you on your quest, you have the help of four derelict robots each running their own simulation for you to explore.

Gameplay is split between a megaman-style sidescrolling jump and shoot, a top down shooter where you explore cyberspace within cyberspace, and RPG-style 4 on 1 battles vs bosses. TDH features a really bizarre artstyle that I can only describe as “uniquely Scott Cawthon” and if you’ve played any of his other games (especially FNAF) you’ll see why. Another interesting feature of this game are the day-night cycles. During the night, you are relegated to exploring the surface world to scavenge for items to improve the derelicts, increase power to the station, or score a few extra credits playing a space invaders style mini-game. Daytime is considerably more busy, requiring you to dive into simulations powered by each derelict in order to seek out and destroy the viruses located within. Once you encounter a virus, you are thrust into a high speed active-time RPG battle where quick thinking and careful planning are required in order to survive.

On that note I have to say that, while most of the game was a fairly interesting experience, the boss battles are incredibly confusing and I managed to clear each one without really understanding what was going on. There is just so much happening on the screen in any given moment and the bosses will interrupt everything very frequently to do a full-screen attack. In any case I won, but I have no idea how or why.

Chaotic boss battles aside, I still really enjoyed The Desolate Hope and you probably will too if you like eccentric hybrid RPGs. Plus, it’s FREE (can’t beat that!)

　　游戏中玩家们操纵一个咖啡机器人去进行一场关于科幻的冒险，而故事的背景设在一个未知星球的边缘，在这有一个谜一样的科幻建筑，而这个名为Lun Infinus的建筑原本是作为人类探索这个星球而制造的。在野心和财富的驱使下，人类因为地球无法居住而去殖民别的星球，但该项目很快就被放弃了，收到的最后指令都已经是三十年前的了。

19177169.review:
While the story seems goo enough, the gameplay fails in many respects. First of all, thne visuals are so overwhelming that you often can not even see the character. Ok, once you played a while you get used to it, but when you start the game, the game graphics looks pretty much the same as the loading screens, so when I first started it, I was waiting for the game to start, until after some time I realized that it already has.

The controls are also pretty bad. You can't reconfigure, so if you don't have an englisch keyboard layout, you may end up with a pretty weirt control scheme. I'm using a german keyboard, where x and z are exchanged, so playing with that means that I always have to cross over for shooting and jumping. This means that for faster gameplay it would be pretty impossible to play. Only way is to swith to an english keyboard layout.

The user interface in general is pretty badly done, so you don't have a clue with what objects you can interact and what is just decoration, especially since, most of the time you play with the keyboard, but sometimes there are menus where you have to switch to the mouse. The whole game is controlled with the cursor keys except the menus, which can be only controlled with the mouse, which is quite unintuite in this context, especially as there is no visual clue (again) that the cursor keys wont work here.

Graphics and sounds are good, but as already mentioned, the graphics in particular is so heavily overloaded and colourfull that it's hard to discern your character.

So all in all, I can't really recommend this game.

18851027.review:
This review is not only going to give you my personal feedback about The Desolate Hope, but is also going to shut up all the people who think that Scott Cawthon is a terrible game developer.

Before Five Nights at Freddy's, Five Nights 2, FNAF 3, and "The Final Chapter", there was a little splendid title called The Desolate Hope, made by everyone's favorite cryptic, Christian, 3DS Max and Clickteam Fusion 2.5 game dev, Scott Cawthon. ;)

References aside, this is a game that everyone should play at least once in their gaming lives, and if not then maybe thrice; especially because this game is FREE! Additionally, if you know someone who hates Scott Cawthon just because of Five Nights at Freddy's, let them try out this indie gem to have them rethink themselves.

Gameplay.
The best part about this game is hands-down the gameplay. It actually combines three types of gameplay styles; top-view, Zelda-like shooting games; Mega Man style, non-linear platforming side-scrollers; and Turn-based RPGs with a unique blend. The RPG style is what I really want to talk most about. The first two gameplay styles are fairly self-explanatory (that is if you know what I'm saying), but Scott has added a very creative twist on turn-based RPG battles. Unlike traditional RPG battles, attacks come seemingly automatically, meaning that you need to react fast to initiate an action. It's a little hard to explain, but I'll try to proceed. Furthermore, there are nice little "microgames" that play during the battles which provide benefits to your party. I apologize for my poor explanantion, but its quite hard for me to put this into words.

Graphics.
I personally enjoy the visuals of this game, then again I also personally enjoy mashed potatoes with ketchup. The game's graphics use 3D images as 2D sprites, which in turn give it a strange feeling of playing a 3D game from the early 2000s, while in reality it actually isn't. Now this feeling, this is something that I like, as it practically tickles my spine with nostalgia. GG, Mr. Cawthon.

Music.
While I'm under the impression that this game's music consists of royalty-free songs, they're still quite catchy and enjoyable. Scott really knows how to direct his music, even if he didn't compose it.

Overall, I reccomend that everyone play this game, especially because it's free and you have nothing to lose. It's a charming and unique title that'll make you enjoy game design and almost wish you could do the same. At least, taht's what it did for me. ;)

18245888.review:
An odd 2D, or turn-based RPG in an even more odd setting (a science fiction, real world-based one where you fight viruses, in this case), which sees you enter metroidvania type worlds with several stages and a boss at the end of each stage, through a melancholic, sad hub, in order to avert an incoming crisis which will affect you and the other characters. Also, the game doesn't let you save your progress at will, and instead auto saves most actions and forces you to deal with failure. Yes, it does sound like Demon's Souls, and while there are no gameplay similarities, I felt it was worth mentioning how similar the atmosphere and pacing of the game was; the difficulty, too. Even if I didn't consciously acknowledge it at the time thanks to all the differences in gameplay, the atmosphere, pacing and structure of the game are basically identical to Demon's Souls, and that similarity really drew me in, and might draw you in. Anyways, the gameplay is unique, in that there are three sorts of gameplay (and small Zelda 1 dungeon style mini-dungeons); the solemn management and searching of the hub world night time management, when you enter a robot's simulated world, with the ruleset of a metroidvania shooter, and when you enter a boss battle, where you go into a turn-based RPG battle where accumulated, I guess I'd say, 'stat tokens' which you've picked up in the metroidvania gameplay add to the stats of all your characters during the fight. I have to say that the story, pacing, atmosphere and enigmatic nature of the game drew me in at the start, but I think that the game escalates the difficulty carelessly. You get some fast-paced challenging fights early on, but the game quickly makes literally every RPG battle consist entirely of one-shot attacks very quickly, ruining the chance to have a more sensible difficulty curve, and also making some boss fights simply too unforgiving.
I would have liked this game, but the boss fights feel far too difficult. Seriously, it feels like you have to do things perfectly to win some of the mid-game and late-game fights, and it feels like the sort of design that is only intuitive to the developer.


In conclusion, I really, really wanted to love this game. The bleak atmosphere and story, the spectacular characterisations of the Derelicts (the robots), their virtual worlds, and their fall from grace, the surprisingly great, if odd and idiosyncratic presentation, set in a world where humans have already died out, the combination of several genres, the lack of hand holding, and the very compelling story. I just think that the game's too hard, and personally, I can't say whether I recommend this game or not. I think I recommend it, solely because I want a sequel to the game so badly; just, hopefully next time, the boss fights aren't so ridiculous, and the metroidvania areas slightly more distinguishable and less maze-like.

18191283.review:
[Análisis is moving to intercept]....

Scott Cawthon es un desarrollador mayoritariamente conocido por crear la ya mundialmente famosa saga "Five Nights at Freddy`s" aunque es una saga excelente en muchos apartados, es triste que gente solo conozca a Scott por FNAF cuando ha creado juegazos como Desolate Hope, juego del que daré mi punto de vista ahora: 
[PROS]

-Mezcla muchos generos y su jugabilidad es excelente: Tanto RPG como plataformero estilo Megaman, este juego dejará mas que satisfechos a los que amen cualquiera de estos géneros anteriores, aunque si eres nuevo en los RPG no te recomendaría empezar por este juego, ya que las batallas son liosas al principio además de que se complican con muchísimas cosas apareciendo en pantalla, aún así, es un juego muy entretenido, las batallas son divertidas cuando les coges el truco y no te aburrirán. 

-Los escenarios son hermosos: Tanto los robots como los niveles son espectaculares y sorprende que un juego hecho por una única persona tenga tanto detalle visual. El diseño de los robots es extemadamente original  y exótico, todos se ven diferentes y únicos además de ser extremadamente espectaculares y los escenarios podrían ser perfectamente usados como fondos de pantalla XD

-Difícil: Este juego es difícil, las batallas son complejas y tendremos que aprendernos al pie de la letra las habilidades de nuestros robots, cada uno tiene un rol diferente en las batallas, y tendremos que lograr que trabajen en harmonía y sean todo lo efectivos posibles para ganar. En cuanto a los niveles 2D con nuestra cafetera coffe, muchas veces acabaremos perdidos en estos, y el hecho de tener un reloj contando el tiempo que nos queda para acabar con nuestro cometido añade tensión a el juego

-Original: Este es uno de esos juegos raros en el buen sentido de la palabra, como ya dije antes, los robots son espectaculares y es genial como logra innovar en un género ya tan usado como los RPG 

-La banda sonora: Soy consciente que no es Scott el compositor, y que toda la banda sonora es extraída de lugares externos, pero está tan bien seleccionada y funciona tan bien con la temática robótica-futurista, que la primera vez en escucharla uno cree que ha sido creada expresamente para The Desolate Hope

-Es gratis: Aunque yo sería capaz de pagar voluntariamente por este juego, que se le va a hacer :/
[CONTRAS]

Confuso al principio: Este juego está completamente en inglés, si eres un paquete en inglés o solo entiendes lo básico como yo, te costará mucho entender todas las mecánicas y tendrás que empezar una nueva partida cuando ya lo entiendas todo, ya que este juego tiene un límite de tiempo de unos 15 días (no son días reales, tiempo de juego) y cada uno que pase cuenta.

Colorines potentes: Las batallas de este juego son completamente locas, muchas cosas en pantalla y colores, aunque esto a mí no me importa, puede hechar atrás a jugadores por esto. El propio juego tiene una advertencia al iniciar, prestadla atención si tenéis algún tipo de enfermedad que pueda interferir con esto.

Y las opciones?: El juego no tiene menú de opciones ._. Ni volumen, ni nada gráfico, el juego no se puede poner en ventana y el volumen lo tienes que vajar con el mezclador de windows (o bajando directamente el volumen de tu PC) Y eso un defecto en el que los juegos de Scott suelen caér muchas veces.

[CONCLUSIÓN]

Es un gran juego, y estando gratis en steam creo que todo el mundo que se haga llamar a si mismos "gamers" deberían por lo menos dignarse a probarlo, pese a sus numerables defectos, es un juego entretenido y bonito, me sorprende como juegos así de buenos son pasados por tanta gente. Ya estoy esperando que Scott confirme The Desolate Hope 2.

17556326.review:
A very charming multi-genre game with beautiful yet surreal enviroments and a nice soundtrack. You play as a coffee machine named Coffee (or rather, a thing in the body of Coffee) in a space station named "Lun Infinus". You enter the rooms in it to find the "Derelicts" (giant robots). In the rooms of them you can also enter a simulation in which they are also present. Simulations are the 2D platformer sections of the game. Each simulation has different goals and upgrades you can buy from the robots.

 In some more hidden sections within these simulations are sub-simulations (a simulation within a simulation). Sub-simulations have wireframe graphics and work similarly to the original The Legend of Zelda (and look kinda like FNaF minigames). You and your rabbit (which only appears here, may I add) go from room to room until some monsters start appearing. Defeating a monster will make a cabbage patch appear which your rabbit then eats and you get some bits for it (bits are the currency of this game). There's also a place to buy upgrades here but I won't go too much into it. The main goal of sub-simulations is actually to unlock conditionals for battles.

Speaking of battles, they're probably the best part of the game! Within these JRPG-like battles, your creepy Derelicts fight against even creepier viruses. I won't go too much into getting to battles because I don't really want to spoil much. If you want to level up your derelicts for said battles, you'll need to go outside during the night phase when simulations are disabled and find some items they happen to collect.

[b]CONCLUSION[/b]: C'mon, it's a free game, why are you still reading this?

17535740.review:
Kostenloser Jump’N’Run Titel mit RPG Elementen
Pro:
[list]
[*]Die Gestaltung der Hintergründe und das Design der Charaktere sind wunderschön und detailreich. In Sachen Grafik mein absoluter Favorit von Scotts Spielen.
[*]Der Soundtrack ist gelungen. Es gibt zwar kein richtiges theme, aber keine der Stücke ist nervig.
[*]Die Geschichte ist interessant.
[*]Epische Bosskämpfe.
[*]Kostenlos.
[*]Der spielbare Hauptcharakter ist eine Kaffeemaschine.
[/list]

Contra:
[list]
[*]Es gibt kaum bis keine Erklärung von Gameplay Elementen wie die Bedeutung der farbigen Eier und der Dinge, die man einkaufen kann.
[*]Nach dem 3./4. Tag wird es teils eintönig, da man nur noch Geld farmt um bessere Gegenstände zu kaufen. Zudem kann man bis auf ganz am Anfang später in allen Gebieten rein. Nachdem man die erkundet hat (deren Größe sich auch in Grenzen hält), kommt fast gar nichts Neues mehr.
[*]Der Schwierigkeitsgrad schwankt. Die Minigegner in den Zonen selber sind nach wenigen Schüssen tot, aber die Bossgegner im RPG Stil sind umso schwerer. 
[*]Es gibt keine Pausentaste.
[*]Man muss hoffen, dass man keinen Fingerkrampf bekommt, da das Spiel nicht für eine europäische Tastatur gemacht ist. Man nutzt X fürs Schießen und Z fürs Springen. Leider liegen diese beiden Tasten recht weit voneinander weg und man muss sich daran gewöhnen (ich wollte anfangs dauernd mit der Pfeilhoch-Taste springen). 
[/list]
Ich habe recht viel Negatives gesagt, aber trotzdem kann ich dieses Spiel empfehlen, da es seinen ganz eigenen Charme besitzt.

17334224.review:
(PROS AND CONS ARE FURTHER DOWN) 
I saw this game in my discovery queue one day, saw that it was free, so I looked at the screenshots to see if I should get it. It looked interesting, so I said to myself "eh, why not" and downloaded it. I started playing it and was very pleasantly surprised. I expected a crappy little Mario rip off and got a cool little game with a witty attitude. I fell in love with the game in the first section of dialogue, to tell the truth. The gameplay itself is a bit wonky, but I've forgiven it for being so much fun. Anyway, after I had been playing for a little while, I loaded up the game and got another little surprise. This game was actually made by Scott Cathon, the same man who made the Five Nights at Freddy's series. This was the biggest surprise that I got because this game is extremely creative and takes little to no inspiration from popular opinion like the FNAF series does. For those of you who don't know what I mean by this, a TON of people are scared of anamatronics, so it only makes sense to make a horror game with them as the main antagonists. While this isn't a horror game, you can see some creepy-looking things in it. There's actually a simulation where you can see something that looks a bit like Freddy Fazbear in structure.* 
PROS AND CONS
Pros:
-Very creative
-Humorous
-Witty
-Interesting
-Well-written
-Lovable characters 
-Beautiful pseudo-3D environment 
-Interesting 3D design (there are 3D areas inside simulations)
-Made by Scott Cawthon (if you like his work)
Cons:
-Wonky control scheme
-A bit confusing
-A bit slow
-Difficult
-Made by Scott Cawthon (if you don't like his work)
So final verdicts? This game is AMAZING and would be worth a cheap price. However, it's free, so no one has an excuse - you NEED to play this amazing game. An honest 10/10 for this game.

*This game was made before FNAF was even an idea, so I know it's not an Easter Egg, but it's still cool to see how his skills in modeling has developed

Was a little hard to get into, because it reminded me of the really old games you get out of a cereal box.
Once I actually managed to figure out what I was doing, it was really fun.

I beat the game in about 6 hours. It's not a very long game. It's also made with an old engine that decides to save progress when you close it, and closing it is as simple as Escape.

I ran into some frame issues. I imagine it was the engine itself. The amount of action on the screen, especially in boss battles at any one time is absolutely amazing and exciting to play.

It should be good for those who played Five Nights at Freddy's, since it's made by the same person.

The ending was awful, but there's a thing you can do after you see the ending, anyways: Go to the Battle Sim at the front of Lun Infinus and try to survive.

Worth it for the action and the soundtrack, in my opinion.
